questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should not:
questions.answerC: Allow the wheels to grip the road.
questions.answerD: Allow the trailer to straighten out.
questions.explanation: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should release the brakes and allow the trailer wheels to regain traction with the road. Do not apply the trailer hand brake to attempt to straighten out the rig because it will only prolong the skid. The application of brakes is what caused the wheels to lock in the first place.

questions.question: To correct a drive-wheel braking skid, a driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Remove your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Turn quickly in the direction of the skid.
questions.answerC: Countersteer after the vehicle is back on course.
questions.explanation: To correct a drive-wheel braking skid, you should first remove your foot from the brake pedal to allow the locked wheels to begin rolling again. Quickly steer in the direction you want to go, then countersteer to prevent your vehicle from skidding in the opposite direction.

questions.question: What is black ice?
questions.answerA: A thick layer of ice on the road
questions.answerB: A thin layer of ice on the road
questions.answerC: Ice that is black from debris on the road
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet.

questions.question: How many seconds of following distance per every 10 feet of vehicle should you maintain when traveling more slowly than 40 mph?
questions.explanation: When traveling at speeds below 40 mph, you should maintain at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle's length. At higher speeds, add an additional second.

questions.question: How should you check your hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should not move.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly move toward the floor.
questions.answerC: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly rise.
questions.answerD: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should be easy to push to the floor.
questions.explanation: To test hydraulic brakes, you should pump the brake pedal three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal and hold for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak.

questions.question: Most drivers are the least alert:
questions.explanation: Fatigue and lack of alertness are major hazards when driving at night. Most people are the least alert at night, especially after midnight.

questions.question: If federal inspectors judge your vehicle to be unsafe, they can:
questions.answerA: Bring you to a garage to have your vehicle fixed.
questions.answerB: Formerly request that you have your vehicle's problems fixed.
questions.answerD: Pull the vehicle out-of-service until it is fixed.
questions.explanation: If a federal or state inspector judges a CMV to be unsafe, they may put it out-of-service until it is fixed.

questions.question: The minimum size of placards identifying hazardous materials is:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be at least 10 and three-quarter inches square.

questions.question: A danger of looking at one mirror for too long is:
questions.answerA: You will be distracted by potential hazards.
questions.answerB: You may not see an upcoming hazard in another location.
questions.answerC: The mirrors may shake and move.
questions.answerD: You may notice a dirty spot on the mirror.
questions.explanation: When checking your mirrors, only look at them quickly. If you concentrate on one mirror for too long, you may travel a substantial distance down the road without being aware of what is ahead, missing important information about upcoming hazards.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse, it is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Drive as fast as possible and get it over with.
questions.answerB: First exit the truck and walk the path to look for obstacles.
questions.answerC: Use only the passenger side mirror.
questions.answerD: Stick your head out the window and look backward.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should first walk around the vehicle to check for hazards in your path of travel. Make frequent use of the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while backing. Always back up as slowly as possible.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection should include:
questions.answerA: A check of the engine oil level.
questions.answerC: Spraying WD-40 into the air filter.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should include a check of components in the engine compartment, including a check of the engine oil level.

questions.question: If a bus is disabled while passengers are still on board:
questions.answerA: Another bus should push the disabled bus to its destination.
questions.answerB: The bus should be towed to its destination.
questions.answerC: The passengers should be asked to push the bus.
questions.answerD: The bus may need be towed to the nearest safe location to discharge the passengers.
questions.explanation: A bus that is disabled while passengers are on board should not be towed or pushed, unless it is absolutely necessary. If needed, the bus should be towed or pushed only as far as the nearest safe location for the passengers to be discharged.

questions.question: When should you check and adjust your mirrors?
questions.answerD: Mirrors do not need to be adjusted.
questions.explanation: The adjustment of mirrors must be checked prior to the start of any trip.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections should be done:
questions.answerA: Differently each time, emphasizing different items.
questions.answerB: The same way each time so you are less likely to forget something.
questions.answerD: By someone other than the driver.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test:
questions.answerA: Applicants will not have to identify the ABS.
questions.answerB: Windshield wipers are not to be addressed.
questions.answerC: Shock absorbers only need to be checked on one axle.
questions.answerD: The steering box should be checked for leaks.
questions.explanation: During the external inspection portion of the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you must verify that the steering box is securely mounted and not leaking.

questions.question: When steering to avoid a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use one hand to steer.
questions.answerB: Keep both hands on the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Not use your mirrors to check other lanes.
questions.answerD: Speed up as you get nearer to the hazard.
questions.explanation: When turning quickly to avoid colliding with a hazard in the roadway, you should always keep both hands on the steering wheel. You must have a firm grip on the wheel to be able to turn quickly.

questions.question: A vehicle inspection:
questions.answerB: Is helpful in identifying minor issues before they become major problems.
questions.answerC: Should not be done by the driver.
questions.answerD: Should be performed once a month.
questions.explanation: A vehicle should be inspected before every trip to help ensure that any small mechanical issues are caught before they become more serious problems. It is better to discover a problem with your vehicle before a drive than after the drive has begun.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.answerD: Wave your arms at other drivers.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes after a tire failure could cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Unless you're about to hit something, stay off of the brake until the vehicle has slowed sufficiently.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is best to always accelerate very slowly.
questions.answerB: So they do not lose control of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: So the driver does not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerD: To be the last vehicle through an intersection.
questions.explanation: Speeding up too quickly on a road with poor traction could cause a driver to lose control of their vehicle. In conditions that cause poor traction, a driver should accelerate especially smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: Water on bridges:
questions.answerA: Usually freezes before water on other parts of a roadway.
questions.answerB: Usually freezes after water on other parts of a roadway.
questions.answerD: Is not a concern in cool weather.
questions.explanation: Bridges will generally freeze before other parts of the roadway. Be careful on bridges when temperatures are around the freezing point.

questions.question: To prevent fatigue while driving, you should:
questions.explanation: A hot, poorly-ventilated area can make a person sleepy. Opening a window, opening a vent, or using the air conditioning can help keep the cab cool and reduce the risk of fatigue.

questions.question: Brake pads should:
questions.answerD: Not have any oil or grease on them.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your brakes, you should verify that the shoes and pads do not have any oil, grease, or brake fluid on them.

questions.question: When using mirrors while driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Look in the mirrors for extended periods of time.
questions.answerD: Use only the driver’s side mirror.
questions.explanation: Focusing on your mirrors for too long can be dangerous because you will have traveled a substantial distance without looking at the road ahead.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, a driver should:
questions.answerC: Cross the tracks before an approaching train reaches the crossing.
questions.explanation: You should approach every railroad crossing with the expectation that a train is coming. Do not rely on signals or your hearing to reliably tell you if a train is present. Always slow down when approaching a crossing. Never try to race a train.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be required to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Point to or touch each item.
questions.answerC: Explain what you are checking and why.
questions.explanation: As a part of earning your CDL, you will have to pass an inspection test and demonstrate that your vehicle is safe for operation. During the vehicle inspection test, you will have to walk around the vehicle and point to or touch each item and explain to the examiner what you are checking and why. You will not have to crawl under the hood or under the vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a driving hazard?
questions.answerC: A police car assisting a motorist on the side of the road
questions.explanation: Passing an accident scene can be hazardous because the people involved in the accident may not be watching traffic, and the scene itself may distract other passing drivers. Ice cream trucks can create hazardous conditions because they attract children who may not pay attention to nearby vehicles. Shoppers near the roadway are often paying attention to stores, not passing traffic.

questions.question: How should you check your hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should not move.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly move toward the floor.
questions.answerC: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly rise.
questions.answerD: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should be easy to push to the floor.
questions.explanation: To test hydraulic brakes, you should pump the brake pedal three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal and hold for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak.

questions.question: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed:
questions.explanation: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed by one-half or more. It can be difficult to stop or turn when operating on a slippery surface, so you must adjust your speed to drive safely under such conditions.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the other driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver doesn’t see you.
questions.explanation: It is always safest to assume that other drivers, bicyclists, and pedestrians don't see you. Be prepared for the possibility that they may suddenly move into your path. It may be safe to lightly tap your horn or flash your lights as you pass.

questions.question: Texting while driving a CMV is:
questions.answerA: Acceptable if the text is work-related.
questions.answerB: Acceptable if there are fewer than 10 words in the text message.
questions.answerC: Encouraged because it is safer than talking on the phone.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving a commercial motor vehicle is both illegal and dangerous. Manually entering text into or reading text from any electronic device is considered texting.

questions.question: A fatigued driver:
questions.answerB: Should take over-the-counter remedies to wake them up.
questions.answerC: May make critical decisions too slowly.
questions.answerD: Is usually more conscientious than a typical driver.
questions.explanation: If you are fatigued, you will not see or react to hazards as quickly as you would if you were fully energized and awake. You will be impaired in making critical decisions.

questions.question: To help your vehicle be seen by others:
questions.answerB: Your lights should be off during the day.
questions.answerC: Your lights should be covered with grease.
questions.answerD: Your lights should only be used in the rain.
questions.explanation: When driving at night, it is important that your lights be clean so that they provide as much light as possible. This will help others to see your vehicle.

questions.question: When driving, keeping space between your vehicle and other vehicles is:
questions.explanation: For the safety of everyone on the road, it is essential that you maintain adequate cushions of space between your vehicle and other vehicles. This will help ensure that if you need to stop your vehicle, you will be able to do so without hitting someone else.

questions.question: You should always be able to stop within:
questions.answerC: Your view of the road ahead.
questions.explanation: You should always make sure that your vehicle will be able to stop within the area of the road that you are able to see. This means that you must slow down whenever conditions reduce visibility.

questions.question: A sign that your vehicle's brakes will need repair is that the:
questions.answerA: Brake pads are not covered in grease.
questions.answerB: Brake pads are not covered in oil.
questions.answerC: The brake pads are worn thin.
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: If driving a vehicle with a manual transmission, you can prevent your vehicle from rolling backward when starting from a stop by:
questions.answerA: Partly engaging the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Placing the vehicle in reverse before moving forward.
questions.answerC: Fully engaging the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Placing the vehicle in neutral before moving forward.
questions.explanation: To prevent rolling backward when starting from a stop, you should partly engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake. Apply the parking brake whenever necessary to prevent your vehicle from rolling back.

questions.question: During a trip, carry-on bags should be:
questions.answerD: Secured to allow the driver to move freely.
questions.explanation: Bus passengers must not be allowed to leave baggage in doorways or aisles during a trip. Baggage and freight must be secured in a way that will allow the driver to move freely and easily; allow riders to exit by any window or door in an emergency; and protect riders from injury if items fall or shift.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.answerD: Wave your arms at other drivers.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes after a tire failure could cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Unless you're about to hit something, stay off of the brake until the vehicle has slowed sufficiently.

questions.question: Buses must never carry ____ in the space occupied by passengers.
questions.explanation: Buses must never carry labeled radioactive materials in the area occupied by passengers.

questions.question: When planning to drive a bus that has been parked for a few days:
questions.answerA: The driver should assume the interior is in good working order.
questions.answerB: The driver should call the local police department.
questions.answerC: The driver should do a walkthrough inspection to ensure no damage has occurred since the last trip.
questions.answerD: The driver should ask the passengers to check the interior of the bus.
questions.explanation: People sometimes damage unattended buses. Before driving a bus that has been unattended, you should check the interior to confirm that everything is in proper condition.

questions.question: The minimum tread depth of all major grooves on tires that are not on the front of a CMV should be a minimum of:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch on the other tires. Tires on the same vehicle should all be the same size.

questions.question: When inspecting the engine compartment, you should not:
questions.answerB: Check the coolant level in the radiator.
questions.answerD: Check the windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the engine compartment, you should check the oil level, coolant level, and windshield washer fluid level, among other things.

questions.question: While driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Develop plans to get out of any dangerous situation that could arise.
questions.answerD: Focus on your own driving and not worry about other drivers.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should consistently check the road ahead for hazards. Develop a plan to deal with any hazards that could arise.

questions.question: When stopping:
questions.answerA: The brake pedal should be pressed down gradually.
questions.answerB: The brake pedal should be pushed down quickly.
questions.answerC: The brake pedal should be pressed down repeatedly, but not held down continuously.
questions.answerD: The amount of force required on the brake pedal will be the same each time you slow or stop.
questions.explanation: Press the brake pedal down smoothly and gradually every time you slow or stop. The amount of brake pressure you need to apply depends on the speed of your vehicle and how quickly you need to stop.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver doesn't see you.
questions.explanation: When passing a pedestrian or another vehicle, you should assume that they don't see you.

questions.question: When about to drive a vehicle with a dual brake system, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up to ensure the fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Wait for air pressure to build in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the engine starts.
questions.answerD: Pump the pedal about 20 times to build pressure, then begin driving.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the compressor to build up pressure to at least 100 psi in both systems.

questions.question: Using an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. While it provides better control, it does not necessarily shorten a vehicle's stopping distance.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning light comes on while you are driving:
questions.answerA: Braking will only occur if there is enough air in the tanks.
questions.answerB: You can brake 14 times before the air in the system runs out.
questions.answerC: You should continue to drive normally and check the brake system when it is convenient.
questions.answerD: You should continue driving, but turn the emergency flashers on to warn other motorists.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning light turns on, you should stop and safely park your vehicle as soon as possible. Controlled braking will be possible only as long as enough air remains in the tanks.

questions.question: All air tanks must include:
questions.explanation: Air brake system tanks must contain drain valves. These valves are used to drain accumulated oil and water from the tanks and may be either manually or automatically operated.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from the tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow water and compressor oil to be removed. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system.

questions.question: How should you test the low pressure warning signal?
questions.answerA: Engage and disable the parking brake.
questions.answerB: Rapidly press and release the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Uncouple and recouple all glad hands.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light functions properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: Air pressure should build up in a single air system within:
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with a single air brake system, after the engine is at operating rpms, the pressure in the air system should generally build from 50 to 90 psi within three minutes.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A double combination vehicle should have a leakage rate no higher than 4 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.answerD: Used to stop the vehicle in normal driving.
questions.explanation: The parking brake should be applied every time you park your vehicle.

questions.question: Water and compressor oil are usually found in the compressed air within an air brake system. Water and compressor oil:
questions.answerA: Are necessary for the proper function of the air brake system.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: Cannot be used with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Should be used on dry pavement.
questions.answerC: Can assist in maintaining control when braking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used if all axles have ABS.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are compatible with air braking systems. ABS helps maintain control of a vehicle and prevents the wheels from locking up during hard braking on slippery surfaces. ABS can still provide benefits even if is present on only one axle.

questions.question: A one-way check valve:
questions.answerA: Drains the water and compressor oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.answerC: Activates the emergency brakes when there is a leak.
questions.answerD: Holds the spring brakes in position until they are used.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are activated, you should never:
questions.answerC: Release air from the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Open the door to the cab.
questions.explanation: Never apply the brake pedal if your spring breaks are activated. Brakes can be damaged if they are subject to both springs and air pressure.

questions.question: If you’re driving and the ABS warning light comes on, it means:
questions.answerB: The ABS has just been activated.
questions.answerC: The ABS is not working properly.
questions.answerD: The ABS needs to be activated.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lights to alert the driver if something is wrong with the braking system. If these lights activate, the driver may have lost ABS on one or more wheels.

questions.question: What can happen if a parking brake is used in very wet weather when temperatures are below freezing?
questions.answerB: The brakes may freeze so the vehicle cannot move.
questions.answerC: The brakes may suddenly release by themselves.
questions.explanation: If you use the parking brakes when the weather is very wet and the temperature is below freezing, the brakes may become frozen, preventing the vehicle from moving.

questions.question: When using the controlled braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half of your usual force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes so the wheels lock.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes with minimal pressure.
questions.explanation: The controlled braking method for emergency stops involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. Keep steering wheel movements small when braking in this way.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: What can happen if the air pressure gets too low in an air brake system?
questions.answerD: The brakes will be very sensitive.
questions.explanation: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can let air out faster than the compressor can replace it, reducing the available air pressure. If the air pressure in an air brake system gets too low, the brakes will no longer work.

questions.question: Foundation brakes are used:
questions.answerC: Only at the driver’s side wheels.
questions.explanation: Foundation brakes are used at each wheel. The most common type is the S-cam drum brake.

questions.question: The air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Hold only enough air for one braking cycle.
questions.answerB: Hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.
questions.answerC: Do not hold air unless there is an emergency.
questions.answerD: Hold enough air for more than 1,000 braking cycles.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Has a single air brake system, but uses two sets of controls.
questions.answerB: Has one air brake system for each side of the truck.
questions.answerC: Has two brakes for each wheel.
questions.answerD: Has two separate air brake systems, but uses a single set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems that use a single set of brake controls. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles. The other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: If braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add ____ to your vehicle's total stopping distance.
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to a vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but allow the wheels to keep rolling.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up and the vehicle stops.
questions.answerD: Apply the emergency brake until the vehicle starts to slow.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, and then the process is repeated.

questions.question: Brake fading is caused when:
questions.answerA: Brakes are not used often enough.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes excessively will cause them to overheat, making them less effective. This is referred to as "fading."

questions.question: If using air tanks with manually operated drains, how often should you drain the tanks?
questions.explanation: To prevent the build up of oil and water in a vehicle's air tanks, manually operated air tank drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Has a single air brake system, but uses two sets of controls.
questions.answerB: Has one air brake system for each side of the truck.
questions.answerC: Has two brakes for each wheel.
questions.answerD: Has two separate air brake systems, but uses a single set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems that use a single set of brake controls. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles. The other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: On a truck with air brakes, the braking system’s air compressor:
questions.answerA: Pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Moves air to the back of the truck.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks. The air compressor is controlled by the air compressor governor.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from the tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow water and compressor oil to be removed. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system.

questions.question: When inspecting your brakes, a slack adjuster should move ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after setting wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems, in which there are two separate braking systems operated by a single set of controls. Each system operates the brakes on different axles.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is ____ in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, a leak in one system:
questions.answerA: Always means there are leaks in both systems.
questions.answerB: May not affect the other system.
questions.answerC: Is not something to worry about.
questions.answerD: Will also affect the other system.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: Test the low pressure warning signal:
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light function properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: When about to drive a vehicle with a dual brake system, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up to ensure the fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Wait for air pressure to build in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the engine starts.
questions.answerD: Pump the pedal about 20 times to build pressure, then begin driving.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the compressor to build up pressure to at least 100 psi in both systems.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Each system has separate air tanks, hoses, and lines.
questions.answerB: The systems share air tanks, but each has its own separate hoses and lines.
questions.answerC: Each system uses the same lines and hoses.
questions.answerD: One system is the main braking system and a second system is ready to be used if the first one fails.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. The systems share a single set of brake controls, but each has its own air tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: If you’re driving and the ABS warning light comes on, it means:
questions.answerB: The ABS has just been activated.
questions.answerC: The ABS is not working properly.
questions.answerD: The ABS needs to be activated.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lights to alert the driver if something is wrong with the braking system. If these lights activate, the driver may have lost ABS on one or more wheels.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be used.
questions.answerB: Shift into a lower gear, then use brakes to supplement the braking effect of the engine.
questions.answerC: The vehicle should be continually downshifted in the place of using the brakes.
questions.answerD: The vehicle should be driven on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, the braking effect of the engine should be your primary method of controlling speed. Shift down to a lower gear before starting down the hill and save the brakes for additional slowing or stopping that may be required by road or traffic conditions.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are on, you should:
questions.answerD: Be especially careful because the brakes may fail.
questions.explanation: You should not apply the brake pedal if the spring brakes are activated. The brakes could be damaged if they are subjected to the force of air pressure and the springs at the same time.

questions.question: If your tractor is equipped with ABS but your trailer is not, the ABS:
questions.answerB: Will still improve your steering control.
questions.answerD: Will allow others to see when you brake.
questions.explanation: In a tractor-trailer combination, if the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the ABS will still improve the driver's steering control. The driver should keep an eye on the trailer and let up on the brakes if the trailer begins to swing out.

questions.question: The most common type of foundation brake used is the:
questions.explanation: The most common type of foundation brake is an s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes is ____ in a minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: What can happen if the air pressure gets too low in an air brake system?
questions.answerD: The brakes will be very sensitive.
questions.explanation: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can let air out faster than the compressor can replace it, reducing the available air pressure. If the air pressure in an air brake system gets too low, the brakes will no longer work.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal should activate:
questions.answerA: When tank pressure falls below 120 psi.
questions.answerB: When tank pressure falls below 60 psi.
questions.answerC: When tank pressure falls below 10 psi.
questions.answerD: When tank pressure falls below 5 psi.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low air pressure warning signal must come on if air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi. This warning signal may come in the form of a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: Do not use the parking brake when parking if:
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.answerD: There is water on the ground.
questions.explanation: A parking brake should not be used if the vehicle's brakes are very hot from use on a steep downgrade or if the brakes are very wet and temperatures are freezing. Using the parking brake when brakes are hot could cause damage to the brakes, and using the brakes when they are wet in freezing weather may cause the brakes to ice up, rendering the vehicle immobile.

questions.question: The emergency brake system uses:
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system.
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system.
questions.answerC: Parts of both the parking and service brake systems.
questions.answerD: Only parts unique to the emergency brake system.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) uses a ____ light to warn that the system is not working properly.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunction lamps are usually yellow. Even if the ABS isn't working properly, a driver will still have access to the vehicle's usual braking functions.

questions.question: A tank endorsement is:
questions.answerC: Required to transport both liquids and gases.
questions.explanation: Subject to certain conditions, a tank endorsement is required to operate a tank vehicle that is used to haul either liquids or gases.

questions.question: The ____ tells a driver how much pressure is in the air tanks.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: If braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add ____ to your vehicle's total stopping distance.
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to a vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: When the spring brakes are activated in a vehicle with air brakes, you should never:
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, never push the brake pedal down when the spring brakes are activated. The combined force of the springs and the pressure of the air brakes could damage the brakes.

questions.question: Buses must never carry:
questions.explanation: While some kinds of hazardous materials may be carried on a bus under certain conditions, tear gas and irritating materials must never be carried. Small arms ammunition labeled ORM-D and emergency medical supplies are permitted.

questions.question: If a driver needs to exit a school bus to ensure all the students have boarded, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Turn off the engine and take the key.
questions.answerC: Ask another bus driver to keep an eye on their bus.
questions.answerD: Ask all students to exit the bus.
questions.explanation: While students are boarding a school bus, if the driver cannot account for a student outside, they should secure the bus, take the key with them, and check around and underneath the bus.

questions.question: While students load and unload a bus, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Watch the process and keep an eye on the students.
questions.explanation: The driver of a school bus should observe students as they enter or exit the bus to ensure that they are not caught in the door or handrails. It is also important to make sure the students have moved a safe distance away from the unloading area after they have exited the bus.

questions.question: On a bus, the driver:
questions.answerA: Is not required to wear a seat belt, but it is recommended.
questions.answerC: Should not wear a seat belt.
questions.answerD: Must wear a seat belt, but only if licensed for less than a year.
questions.explanation: The driver's seat on a bus should be equipped with a seat belt, which should always be used.

questions.question: Bus accidents occur most frequently:
questions.explanation: Bus accidents most commonly occur at intersections. Use special caution when driving where you may encounter an increased number of vehicles and pedestrians.

questions.question: If the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is malfunctioning:
questions.answerA: You will not have any brakes.
questions.answerC: You should only use the parking brake to stop.
questions.answerD: You should stop driving and wait for the ABS to work again.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. If ABS is not working, the basic braking functions on a vehicle will still remain, so the driver can continue to drive and brake normally.

questions.question: Buses must never carry:
questions.answerB: Any amount of solid Class 6 poisons.
questions.explanation: Buses may never be used to transport radioactive materials. Division 2.3 poison gas, liquid Class 6 poisons, tear gas, and irritating materials are also not permitted to be carried by bus.

questions.question: When boarding the school bus, students should:
questions.answerD: Try to take two stairs at a time.
questions.explanation: Students should board a school bus slowly in a single-file line while using the handrail.

questions.question: When you are approaching a bus stop, the students on your bus should:
questions.answerB: Stand up and collect their belongings.
questions.answerC: Walk to the front of the bus and prepare to exit.
questions.explanation: Students on a school bus should remain seated until they are told otherwise. It is unsafe for students to walk around the bus while it is moving.

questions.question: Before driving a bus that has been left unattended:
questions.answerA: The vehicle should be thoroughly washed.
questions.answerB: Air should be removed from tires.
questions.answerC: The interior should be checked for damage.
questions.answerD: The driver should look for any animals that may have gotten onboard.
questions.explanation: People sometimes damage unattended buses. When inspecting a bus that has been left unattended, you should do a walkthrough to check the interior for damage.

questions.question: If in the vicinity of a school where students are present and a helper is not available, a driver:
questions.answerB: May back the vehicle, but only if the path looks clear.
questions.answerC: May back the vehicle, but at a speed no faster than 10 mph.
questions.explanation: A bus must not be backed at a school while students are in the vicinity unless a responsible person is present to guide the driver.

questions.question: If a bus is equipped with outside convex mirrors, they will be located:
questions.explanation: Outside convex mirrors on a school bus are located below the outside flat mirrors. They are used to see a wide view of traffic, clearance, and students around the bus.

questions.question: Before leaving a bus stop, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Make sure no students are running to catch the bus.
questions.answerB: Make sure students have placed their backpacks in the aisle.
questions.answerC: Make sure students have opened the emergency vent.
questions.answerD: Make sure students are facing the rear of the bus.
questions.explanation: Before pulling away from a bus stop, a driver should make sure that there are no students running to catch the bus.

questions.question: When unloading students at a school, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Secure the bus by turning off the ignition switch.
questions.answerB: Keep the key in the ignition and leave the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Read a book while students unload.
questions.explanation: When dropping children off at a school, the bus driver should secure the bus by turning off the ignition. The driver should remove the key if they leave the driver's compartment.

questions.question: If a tornado is approaching and the bus is evacuated, where should students go?
questions.explanation: If students are evacuated due to a school bus being in the direct path of a sighted tornado, the driver should lead them to shelter in a nearby building. If no such shelter is available, the driver should escort them to a nearby ditch or culvert. They should avoid areas that may be subject to flash flooding and should be far enough from the bus that it would not fall on them if it tipped over.

questions.question: If you must back up at a student pick-up point, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up before the students board the bus.
questions.answerB: Let the students board the bus and then back up.
questions.answerC: Let half the students board the bus and then back up toward the other half of the students.
questions.answerD: Tell the students to wait at the stop and then back toward the stop.
questions.explanation: If you must back up a school bus at a student pick-up point, be sure to pick up all students before you begin backing up. When backing, it is especially important to keep an eye out for latecomers.

questions.question: While the vehicle is in operation, emergency exits should be:
questions.explanation: Any emergency door should be unlocked, but securely latched, while a vehicle is in motion.

questions.question: Why should a school bus stop a short distance from students who are waiting to board?
questions.answerA: The students will have to walk to the bus, making it easier for the driver to watch their movements.
questions.answerB: The students will usually be waiting on a sidewalk.
questions.answerC: The students may get scared of a school bus coming toward them.
questions.explanation: When being stopped to load students, a school bus should stop at least 10 feet away from the waiting students. This forces the students to walk toward the bus, making it easier for the driver to keep track of their movements.

questions.question: A school bus stop:
questions.answerA: Can be added by the driver if there is a need.
questions.answerB: Should be voted on by the students.
questions.answerC: May change, depending on weather conditions.
questions.answerD: Should be established by the proper school district authorities.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should not alter the location of a bus stop without written authorization of the appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: Buses must never carry ____ in the space occupied by passengers.
questions.explanation: Buses must never carry labeled radioactive materials in the area occupied by passengers.

questions.question: If a bus has a brake and accelerator interlock system, the system should:
questions.answerA: Be turned off in most situations.
questions.answerB: Only be used in inclement weather.
questions.answerC: Never be used in place of the parking brake.
questions.explanation: Urban transit buses may have a brake and accelerator interlock system, which applies the brakes and holds the throttle in an idle position while the rear door is open. This system should not be used as a substitute for the parking brake.

questions.question: Gasoline:
questions.answerA: Can be brought onto a bus.
questions.answerB: May never brought onto a bus.
questions.answerC: Can be stored in the passenger compartment of a bus during long trips.
questions.answerD: Should be stored in glass containers.
questions.explanation: Bus drivers and passengers should not be permitted to bring common hazardous items, such as gasoline or car batteries, onto a bus.

questions.question: If a bus stalls on a railroad track, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Evacuate the bus and get everyone far away from the tracks.
questions.answerB: Keep everyone inside the bus and try to wave the train down to make it stop.
questions.answerC: Keep everyone inside the bus and wait for help.
questions.answerD: Keep everyone inside the bus and call a tow truck.
questions.explanation: If a school bus becomes stalled or trapped on railroad tracks, the driver should immediately evacuate everyone from the bus. To best avoid flying debris from the bus being struck by a train, the students should be led far away from the bus at an angle that is in the direction of any oncoming train.

questions.question: In the event of a bus evacuation, students should be led at least ____ away from the road.
questions.explanation: If it is necessary to evacuate a school bus, students should be led by the driver in the direction of oncoming traffic to a safe location that is at least 100 feet off the road. This will help to ensure that they are not hit by flying debris if another vehicle hits the bus.

questions.question: If in the vicinity of a school where students are present and a helper is not available, a driver:
questions.answerB: May back the vehicle, but only if the path looks clear.
questions.answerC: May back the vehicle, but at a speed no faster than 10 mph.
questions.explanation: A bus must not be backed at a school while students are in the vicinity unless a responsible person is present to guide the driver.

questions.question: On a bus, the driver:
questions.answerA: Does not need to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: Must always wear a seat belt.
questions.answerC: Must wear a seat belt, but only during usual school hours.
questions.answerD: Must wear a seat belt, but only if they have been licensed for less than a year.
questions.explanation: The driver's seat of a bus should be equipped with a seat belt, which must always be used by the driver.

questions.question: At a passive railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: The decision to proceed rests with each driver.
questions.answerB: The decision to proceed should be based on a control device.
questions.answerC: The decision to proceed should be based on surrounding vehicles.
questions.answerD: The decision to proceed is left to passengers in each vehicle.
questions.explanation: Passive railroad crossings are not controlled by any traffic control devices. At such crossings, it is entirely a driver's responsibility to determine when it is safe to cross the tracks.

questions.question: Hazardous materials must be marked with all of the following, except:
questions.answerD: The phone number of a contact person.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials must be marked with the name of the material, the identification number, and the appropriate hazard label. Do not transport a hazardous material unless you are positive that it is permitted.

questions.question: To ensure passenger safety, be sure the check the condition of:
questions.explanation: Before beginning a trip, you should check in the interior of the bus to ensure rider safety. To help all passengers remain safe while you are on the road, you should make sure all the handholds, railings, signaling devices, floor coverings, and emergency exit handles are in proper working condition.

questions.question: Carry-on bags should be placed:
questions.answerA: In front of the back door.
questions.answerB: In front of the front door.
questions.answerC: In a location that allows easy access to all emergency exits.
questions.explanation: Bus passengers should not be allowed to leave baggage in any doorway or aisle. Baggage and freight must be secured in a manner that will prevent damage, allow the driver to move freely and easily, allow riders to exit by any window or door in an emergency, and protect riders from injury if the items fall or shift.

questions.question: If a bus is equipped with outside convex mirrors, they will be located:
questions.explanation: Outside convex mirrors on a school bus are located below the outside flat mirrors. They are used to see a wide view of traffic, clearance, and students around the bus.

questions.question: Explain passenger comfort and safety rules:
questions.answerA: At the beginning of the trip.
questions.answerB: At the end of the trip.
questions.explanation: Many charter carriers have rules about passengers smoking, drinking, and using music players while on the bus. Explaining passenger safety and comfort rules at the beginning of a trip is often an effective way to avoid trouble later on.

questions.question: Before driving a bus that has been parked for a few days, a driver:
questions.answerA: Can assume the interior is in good working condition.
questions.answerB: Should call the local police department to inspect the bus.
questions.answerC: Should do a walkthrough inspection to make sure no damage has occurred since the last trip.
questions.answerD: Should ask passengers to check the interior of the bus.
questions.explanation: People sometimes damage unattended buses. Before beginning a trip, a bus driver should check the interior of a bus to verify that key systems are in good condition for rider safety.

questions.question: An active railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: Has a traffic control device installed at the crossing.
questions.answerB: Does not have any traffic control devices installed at the crossing.
questions.answerC: Is characterized by having at least 10 vehicles cross the tracks every hour.
questions.explanation: Active railroad crossings use installed traffic control devices to regulate traffic. These devices can be in the form of flashing red lights, warning bells, and/or gates. The directions of devices controlling railroad crossings must always be followed.

questions.question: As a general rule, student safety is best maintained by:
questions.answerA: Keeping the students on the bus.
questions.answerB: Letting some students evacuate the bus, while others stay on.
questions.explanation: In most emergency situations, students will be safest and best kept under control if they do not evacuate the school bus.

questions.question: Carry-on bags should be placed:
questions.answerA: In front of the back door.
questions.answerB: In front of the front door.
questions.answerC: In a location that allows access to all emergency exits.
questions.explanation: Baggage should not be left in the aisle or doorways of a bus. Baggage and cargo must be secured in a way that prevents damage, allows the driver to move freely and easily, permits riders to exit by any window or door in the event of an emergency, and protects riders from injury if items fall or shift.

questions.question: Rules regarding passenger comfort, such as smoking guidelines, should:
questions.answerA: Not be mentioned unless there is a rule violation.
questions.answerB: Only be mentioned if a passenger specifically asks about something.
questions.answerC: Be announced at the start of the trip.
questions.answerD: Be discussed individually with each passenger.
questions.explanation: Many charter and intercity carriers have rules about passengers smoking, drinking, and using music players while on the bus. Explaining passenger rules at the start of a trip is often an effective way to avoid trouble later on.

questions.question: A bus driver does not need to stop when approaching:
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing while driving a bus, you must stop between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest track to look and listen for any approaching trains. Only proceed once you are certain that there are no approaching trains. You do not need to stop at streetcar crossings; if a police officer or flagger is directing traffic; if there is a green traffic signal at the crossing; or at crossings marked "exempt" or "abandoned."

questions.question: The overhead inside rearview mirror:
questions.answerA: Allows the driver to see what is happening inside of the bus.
questions.answerB: Allows the driver to see what is happening outside of the bus.
questions.explanation: In a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: If you must back up at a student pick-up point, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up before the students board the bus.
questions.answerB: Let the students board the bus and then back up.
questions.answerC: Let half the students board the bus and then back up toward the other half of the students.
questions.answerD: Tell the students to wait at the stop and then back toward the stop.
questions.explanation: If you must back up a school bus at a student pick-up point, be sure to pick up all students before you begin backing up. When backing, it is especially important to keep an eye out for latecomers.

questions.question: When driving a tractor-trailer equipped with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop harder than you would otherwise.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Brake using less pressure than you would otherwise use.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would in a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: The emergency air line:
questions.answerA: Is controlled by the foot brake.
questions.answerB: Is connected to the relay valves.
questions.answerC: Supplies air to the trailer air tanks.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks on a combination vehicle, and the second is to control the emergency brakes.

questions.question: Using the trailer hand brake while experiencing a trailer jackknife will:
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a trailer jackknife, you can help your tires regain traction by releasing the brakes. Using a trailer hand brake while experiencing a skid will only cause the skid to continue.

questions.question: Compared to other commercial motor vehicles, combination vehicles need more space on the road because they are longer and they:
questions.answerA: Need more space to turn and stop.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles need more space on the road than other commercial vehicles because they are longer and need more space to turn and stop. It is especially important to properly manage space when you are operating a combination vehicle.

questions.question: A trailer will be most likely to swing around when:
questions.explanation: An empty trailer will require a longer stopping distance than a loaded trailer. Additionally, a trailer is most likely to swing out and strike other vehicles when it is lightly loaded or empty.

questions.question: Which of the following types of vehicles is most prone to the “crack-the-whip" effect?
questions.explanation: Double and triple combinations are the most vulnerable to turning over as a result of the "crack-the-whip" effect.

questions.question: To test the trailer service brakes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.answerC: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.explanation: To test the trailer service brakes, you should first ensure that the braking system has a normal air pressure level, then release the parking brake. You should then move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control. If the trailer service brakes are working properly, you will feel the brakes activate.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to skid, the driver should:
questions.explanation: If your trailer starts to skid while you are braking, you should release the brakes and allow them to begin to regain traction. Once its wheels have regained their grip on the road, the trailer will begin to straighten out and follow the tractor.

questions.question: To help prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Placed as high as possible inside the trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed as low as possible inside the trailer.
questions.answerC: Placed on the passenger side of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Placed on the driver’s side of the trailer.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a rollover, the weight of cargo in a trailer should be kept as low to the ground as possible. Weight should not be placed primarily on one side of the trailer as this could make the trailer lean, increasing the risk of a rollover.

questions.question: The easiest way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is to:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to determine if the trailer has left the lane.
questions.answerC: Release the brake pedal and then push it down again.
questions.answerD: Watch the jackknife warning light on the control panel.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to spot a trailer skid is to use your mirrors. Any time you brake hard, check your mirrors to ensure that your trailer is still in its proper position.

questions.question: When traveling more slowly than 40 mph, maintain at least ____ of following distance per every 10 feet of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. Follow the same formula when traveling at faster speeds, then add one additional second to your following distance. Remember that larger vehicles require more space to stop than smaller vehicles.

questions.question: When driving a combination rig, following distance should be:
questions.answerB: Shorter than when driving a single vehicle.
questions.answerC: About the same as when driving a single vehicle.
questions.answerD: Longer than when driving a single vehicle.
questions.explanation: In comparison to driving a single vehicle, you should maintain an extended following distance when driving a combination rig. Combinations require longer stopping distances than smaller vehicles.

questions.question: Trailers with low underneath clearance may be difficult to drive:
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: After finishing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Leave the rear shut-off valves open.
questions.answerD: Leave the emergency line valve open.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves to listen for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: To lower the risk of a rollover, you should:
questions.answerA: Load the cargo as far forward as possible.
questions.answerB: Load the cargo as far back as possible.
questions.answerC: Load the cargo as low as possible.
questions.answerD: Stack the cargo as high as possible.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerA: Regularly to activate the trailer brakes in all driving conditions.
questions.answerB: Only to test the trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Only in inclement weather when the trailer may skid.
questions.answerD: Only if the trailer is carrying a load.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should be used only to test the trailer brakes. It should not be used while driving because it may cause the trailer to skid.

questions.question: When glad hands are coupled, the seals should be pressed together at an angle of:
questions.explanation: When coupling, be sure to couple the proper glad hands. When glad hands are connected, the seals should be pressed together at a 90-degree angle.

questions.question: When driving a bobtail tractor, you should be aware that:
questions.answerB: Bobtails cannot drive as fast as tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerC: Bobtails are more difficult to stop than tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerD: Bobtails are illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to bring the bobtail to a complete stop than it would a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: To prevent a trailer from rolling over, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up when nearing a corner.
questions.answerC: Take on-ramps faster than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a rollover when driving a combination vehicle, you should keep the weight of the cargo as low to the ground as possible and drive slowly around turns.

questions.question: Trailers built before 1975 are:
questions.answerB: Not required to have spring brakes.
questions.explanation: Trailers built before 1975 are not required to have spring brakes. When parking a trailer without spring brakes, be sure to use wheel chocks to prevent the trailer from rolling.

questions.question: If your trailer begins to drift off course while you are backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue trying to back up without stopping.
questions.answerB: Turn the top of your steering wheel in the direction of the drift.
questions.answerC: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the drift.
questions.answerD: Return the steering wheel to the 12 o’clock position.
questions.explanation: If your trailer begins to drift while you are backing, you should correct the drift immediately by turning the top of the steering wheel in the direction of the drift.

questions.question: When driving a bobtail tractor, you should be aware that:
questions.answerB: Bobtails cannot drive as fast as tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerC: Bobtails are more difficult to stop than tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerD: Bobtails are illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to bring the bobtail to a complete stop than it would a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: What is a bobtail?
questions.answerC: A tractor that goes faster than the speed limit
questions.answerD: A tractor that goes slower than the speed limit
questions.explanation: Tractors without semi-trailers are referred to as bobtail tractors. Operating a bobtail tractor requires drivers to exercise caution.

questions.question: To lower the risk of a rollover, you should:
questions.answerA: Load the cargo as far forward as possible.
questions.answerB: Load the cargo as far back as possible.
questions.answerC: Load the cargo as low as possible.
questions.answerD: Stack the cargo as high as possible.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: What does the trailer air supply control look like?
questions.answerA: It is a square blue knob.
questions.answerB: It is a triangular yellow knob.
questions.answerC: It is an eight-sided red knob.
questions.answerD: It is a circular orange knob.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles, the trailer air supply control is an eight-sided red knob. It's used to control the tractor protection valve.

questions.question: Before a drive, ensure that air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Opening the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerB: Closing the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerC: Disconnecting air supply lines and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerD: Rolling each trailer down a hill and testing the brakes.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves in the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: What is off-tracking?
questions.answerA: When a vehicle’s front wheels follow a different path than its rear wheels
questions.answerB: When a vehicle's wheels all follow the exact same path
questions.answerC: When a load shifts during a turn
questions.answerD: When a vehicle's wheels run over a curb during a turn
questions.explanation: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is known as off-tracking, or "cheating."

questions.question: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and:
questions.answerA: Detach the jaws from around the kingpin.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking lever is in the "emergency" position.
questions.answerD: Look into the back of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and look into the back of the fifth wheel. Ensure that the fifth wheel jaws are secured around the shank of the kingpin.

questions.question: When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that you:
questions.answerB: Make sure there is a large enough gap for your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Expect other drivers to make room for your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Let other drivers wave you into their lane.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enough gap in traffic for you to safely do so.

questions.question: When lightly loaded, combination vehicles:
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with most of the weight in the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When a combination vehicle is lightly loaded, it may have poor traction. It is very easy for wheels to lock up on lightly-loaded vehicles when they are being stopped.

questions.question: When driving a trailer with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Not depress the brakes as much as you would when driving a vehicle without ABS.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerC: Brake as you would when driving a vehicle without ABS.
questions.answerD: Try to not brakes as often as you would when driving a vehicle without ABS.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would if operating a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: An air supply control lever should be in its "normal" position when you are:
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "normal" position, it is properly set for you to pull a trailer.

questions.question: An air supply control in its "emergency" position will:
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "emergency" position, the air supply will be stopped and the trailer emergency brakes will be applied.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerA: Does not change braking in any way.
questions.answerC: Will allow the driver additional control over their vehicle when braking.
questions.answerD: Will cause extra strain on the other axles.
questions.explanation: Having an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) on only the trailer, or even on just one axle, will still provide a driver with additional control over the trailer when braking.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover, a driver should:
questions.explanation: Rollovers can happen when a combination vehicle is turned too quickly. To help prevent the risk of rollover, it is important to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low by loading cargo as close to the ground as possible.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to skid, the driver should:
questions.explanation: If your trailer starts to skid while you are braking, you should release the brakes and allow them to begin to regain traction. Once its wheels have regained their grip on the road, the trailer will begin to straighten out and follow the tractor.

questions.question: Simply changing lanes can cause:
questions.answerA: A “crack-the-whip” effect, resulting in a rollover.
questions.answerC: Confusion over which lane the driver is hoping to use.
questions.answerD: Other drivers to reduce their speed.
questions.explanation: Due to the "crack-the-whip" effect caused by rearward amplification, changing lanes too quickly in a combination vehicle can result in a rollover.

questions.question: If a trailer is too high:
questions.answerA: It will not make a difference when coupling.
questions.explanation: Before coupling together a tractor and a trailer, you should make sure the trailer is at the proper height. If the trailer is too low, the trailer nose may be damaged. If the trailer is too high, it may not be able to couple correctly.

questions.question: After coupling, there should be ____ between the upper and lower fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, be sure to inspect all couplings. There should be no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.
